paragraphs.text: Can solar power replace oil in the Middle East?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: The rise of shale has posed a rare challenge to Middle Eastern oil, culminating in a global oil price war and moving OPEC members to slash profits to retain market share
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But at a time
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when OPEC's hegemony over the oil markets has been challenged
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: let us not forget there is another abundant natural energy resource the Middle East possesses - the sun
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The abundance of sunlight (and therefore solar power) offers Middle Eastern energy producers an opportunity to achieve first-move advantage in a market that appears to be the longer-term future of energy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In light of recent instability in oil markets, the importance of alternative renewable energies, particularly solar, has become all the more pronounced
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The drop in oil prices has precipitated an efficiency rush in energy production in all producer nations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the US, oil producers are leaving no stone unturned in the hunt to become as efficient and sustainable as possible
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In Europe, there is a renewed push for renewable energy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: some countries like the UK are also pursuing nuclear energy as a longer-term solution
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In the Gulf, there are similar measures taking place to become more efficient in a more competitive energy market
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: increasingly, they are turning to solar to achieve it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Domestic budgets
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The Gulf states remains one of the biggest oil producers in the world, and make up the biggest exporting members of OPEC, especially Saudi Arabia
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: While some of these countries can afford to swallow current oil prices for now
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they will nonetheless find it difficult to maintain their domestic budgets
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - all OPEC countries chose to cut prices in order to hold onto market share
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: this means slashing profit
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It would not be unprecedented for these countries to encounter domestic trouble
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The other, more serious concerns for these major oil producers, is the increasing consumer demand in their own countries
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In past decades, the region has been able to sustain luxury alongside completely inefficient energy policies through government subsidies
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the entire energy outlook for the region is changing rapidly
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Rising populations, a growing middle class, industry diversification and increasing consumerism has turned a number of countries in the Gulf region into major energy consumers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In Saudi Arabia, oil accounts for over 65 percent of all electricity production
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: in Kuwait it is 71 percent
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: in Lebanon it is 94 percent
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: in Yemen it's an astonishing 100 percent
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: This represents an energy policy that is inefficient and in the long run - unsustainable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Saudi Arabia is the biggest petroleum consumer in the region
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: it is the world's second biggest consumer of total primary energy, 60 percent of which is petroleum-based
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: But most importantly, it paints a distressing future for the region's oil export industry
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: consumer demand continues to grow
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it will eventually result in downward pressure on oil exports and could start affecting subsidies
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Without a robust and efficient energy balance in the region, it will inevitably lead to these producer nations becoming less profitable with a weaker export outlook
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And with competitors in the oil market like Russia, Iran and the North American shale, this is a long-term dynamic that will undermine Middle East's global energy dominance
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the possibilities associated with harnessing Middle Eastern solar energy could be a game-changer
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Solar is becoming much cheaper to invest in, and now has an established and ever improving infrastructure
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Substantial investment in solar will act as a shield for the region's more valued commodity; oil
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Saudi Arabia alone for example, could have made$43.8bn in additional oil revenue in 2013 were it not for its spiralling domestic consumption
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: It also would have acted as a massive stimulus to the country's finances
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Earlier this year, Saudi Aramco, the state oil company, announced it would be making solar energy investments across the country in an attempt to diversify the country's energy supplies
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It is also expected to conserve the country's oil resources primarily for export
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It has been a slow process but is nonetheless an important one for the future of the solar energy sector
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One of the biggest success variables for any solar energy project is not just investment, but location
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Middle East's solar industry is one of the most economically sustainable and acts as the best conserver of the region's oil resources
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Investment opportunity
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: It is also a very strong investment opportunity for those looking to invest in a sustainable, long-term energy sector with a ready market and significantly lower start-up costs then depleting energy exploration
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But these new developments would also have another important advantage for the Middle East; a cleaner environment
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The use of petroleum for electricity generation has made the Middle East's air quality one of the poorest in the world
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Twenty-nine of the world's most polluted cities are in the MENA region
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Recent energy challenges could have very costly consequences for the region
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: left unaddressed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they could also reap huge rewards
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: met with robust energy reforms and additional investment in alternative energies, especially solar
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And there are positive signs for the region
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Saudi Arabia alone has announced a $109bn investment plan to generate a third of its electricity
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Qatar has also made solar energy agreements with major renewable energy companies as part of its commitments to the Solar GCC alliance
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: How these measures materialise over the next decade or so remains to be seen
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there is room for optimism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What's
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: more
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Middle East's unrivalled solar potential means that theoretically, it can become more then a just a world leader in fossil fuel production
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it can become a world leader in renewable energy production as well
paragraphs.label: assumption
